channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: In Unprecedented Times, Congress Evades Responsibility
item.description: On constitutional matters of war powers and tariffs, Republican lawmakers have abandoned the field to Trump.

item.title: Orban Seeks Exemption From U.S. Penalties on Russian Oil Imports
item.description: Hungary hopes that flattering Trump will keep Russian energy flowing to the country.

item.title: Orban Showers Trump With Praise to Avoid U.S. Sanctions
item.description: Hungary hopes that flattering Trump will keep Russian energy flowing to the country.

item.title: Africa Needs a Continental Body With Teeth
item.description: The African Union has become a back-scratching club of heads of state.

item.title: 5 Novelists on Their Favorite Climate Fiction
item.description: Sometimes, literature meets the moment better than diplomacy.

item.title: What in the World?
item.description: Test yourself on the week of Nov. 1: Mexico and Peru have a falling-out, European Union leaders reach an agreement, and the Abraham Accords get a new taker.

item.title: The Man Who Could Topple Orban
item.description: How Peter Magyar went from a former Fidesz insider to Hungary’s most popular politician.

item.title: The Surprising History of Egypt’s ‘Crazy Tomatoes’
item.description: How an ordinary ingredient became a symbol of collective complaint.

item.title: The Forgotten Visionary of U.S. War in Latin America
item.description: Lucius Shepard’s hallucinogenic stories anticipated Trump’s war fantasies.

item.title: Cover Story newsletter: The great relationship recession
item.description: An exclusive look at how we designed our cover

item.title: Del Toro’s Netflix ‘Frankenstein’ Feels Like a Classic
item.description: The Mexican director has finally made the movie he’s dreamt about since childhood.

item.title: The Case for a European-Chinese Green Pact
item.description: China and Europe share a strategic interest in advancing the green transition not only within their own borders, but also across emerging markets and developing economies. With America waging war on the global climate agenda, the world's remaining climate leaders must find a way to deepen ties.

item.title: Elon Musk’s $1trn pay deal is a troubling display of corporate capture
item.description: He has Tesla and its board wrapped around his finger

item.title: Can peptides give you superpowers?
item.description: The “Wolverine stack” is supposed to boost healing and recovery

item.title: How Oil Came to Define Venezuela’s Economy
item.description: The economic shocks precede Chávez and Maduro.

item.title: Zohran Mamdani lost in parts of NYC that look most like America
item.description: Our analysis shows why his victory is no model for Democrats elsewhere

item.title: Hemedti: warlord, power-broker and the new sultan of Darfur
item.description: Now in control of his own statelet, the paramilitary leader will determine the future of Sudan’s devastating civil war

item.title: The Use and Abuse of ‘Narco-Terrorism’
item.description: From Afghanistan to Venezuela, the misleading term has inspired decades of misguided policies against real problems.

item.title: Europe Must Find Its Own Way in Ukraine
item.description: At a time when the European Union is enduring many hardships, it has no interest in letting the war in Ukraine drag on endlessly. But it does have interests there, and it cannot afford to agree to a settlement that ignores them.

item.title: Is Takaichi Sanae Japan’s Margaret Thatcher?
item.description: Japan's first female prime minister, Takaichi Sanae, has come to power at a critical moment for Japan. If she is to be the leader the country needs, she will have to deliver on three fronts: reining in inflation, increasing female labor-force participation, and navigating a fraught geopolitical environment.

item.title: Climate Issue newsletter: China, the climate superpower
item.description: Oli Morton, a senior editor at The Economist, puts the country’s astonishing green growth into context

item.title: The Climate Issue newsletter: China, the climate superpower
item.description: Oli Morton, a senior editor at The Economist, puts the country’s astonishing green growth into context

item.title: Czechia: China’s Punitive Silence on Replay
item.description: Beijing weaponizes communication channels to compel compliance, signal grievance, assert status, and inflict punishment.

item.title: Why Climate Finance Is Not Enough
item.description: Heading into this month's United Nations Climate Conference, evidence is mounting that the Global North will not meet its funding promises. But rich countries could still demonstrate good faith through another form of solidarity: sharing the knowledge, technology, and intellectual property that underpin the green transition.

item.title: Sanctions, the Taliban, and an Iranian Port: The Uncertain Future of India’s Kabul Route
item.description: India’s approach to the Taliban has gradually shifted from purely humanitarian aid to a focus on trade and transit.

item.title: Trump Should Oust Maduro
item.description: U.S. military might can help democratize Venezuela without sending troops.

item.title: Trump Is Alienating Southeast Asia
item.description: Tariffs and inattention have pushed regional states toward China.

item.title: Toward Humanist Superintelligence
item.description: For AI to deliver its promised benefits, it must be designed in the humanist tradition, with people remaining unequivocally in control, and with human dignity always coming first. Systems that can endlessly improve and adopt their own purposes must be avoided at all costs.

item.title: Latin America’s Pivot to Asia
item.description: Chile, Mexico, and Peru announced new trade talks at APEC.

item.title: COP30 and China’s Tibetan Plateau Paradox
item.description: China’s stewardship of the Third Pole will shape not only Asia’s water security but the credibility of global climate cooperation.

item.title: When Central Asia Came to Washington
item.description: The Trump administration’s transactional style was on fully display, with savvy Central Asian businessmen just as keen to get in on a deal.

item.title: Why a Full-blown War Against the Taliban May Not Benefit Pakistan
item.description: The Pakistani economy is in dire straits. A prolonged war could bleed its economy further.

item.title: Gulf investment pledges in Africa soar
item.description:
Although official estimates on volumes and values differ…

The post Gulf investment pledges in Africa soar appeared first on Economist Intelligence Unit.

item.title: A Complacent Pentagon Needs to Learn From Ukraine
item.description: The Europeans are deeply engaged with Kyiv on defense technology, but Washington is lagging behind.

item.title: Trump’s G2 Moment: Dawn of a New World Order?
item.description: The emergence of a robust G-2 dialogue may signal a transition from a unipolar world to a bipolar one.

item.title: Building Tomorrow’s Leaders: How Global Schools Group Redefines Education
item.description: The international academic network champions innovation and inclusivity across 64 campuses and counting worldwide, preparing ethical citizens for a changing future.

item.title: A New Name for New Delhi?
item.description: A BJP parliamentarian recently called for the renaming of the Indian capital as Indraprastha.

item.title: In Search of the AI Bubble’s Economic Fundamentals
item.description: The rise of generative AI has triggered a global race to build semiconductor plants and data centers to feed the vast energy demands of large language models. But as investment surges and valuations soar, a growing body of evidence suggests that financial speculation is outpacing productivity gains.

item.title: Chinese Rhetoric on Okinawa and the Ryukyu Islands
item.description: Beijing is trying to drive a wedge between Okinawa and Tokyo.

item.title: People, Finance, Nature: What COP30 Means for Southeast Asia
item.description: After years of patchy progress, the upcoming U.N. conference offers an opportunity for the region to take significant strides toward its climate goals.

item.title: Indonesian Activists Protest Plans to Grant Former President Suharto ‘Hero’ Status
item.description: The proposal to recognize the authoritarian former leader is a sign of the historical revisionism that has gained momentum under President Prabowo Subianto.

item.title: To Counter China, Look to the ‘Other Trilat’
item.description: The U.S.-Philippines-Japan partnership needs institutionalization.

item.title: Milei’s Tightrope Act
item.description: Why the Argentine president will struggle to exploit his new mandate.

item.title: Global Climate Policy Is Broken
item.description: Fixating on emissions won’t decarbonize the world’s economy.

item.title: A Week in Chengdu
item.description: Our traveling correspondent finds a native animal almost too cute to bear.
